stories.article_summary: Article content too short to summarize effectively.

main_themes: Limited discussion with detailed analysis available
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The comments reflect a critical view of AI tools, highlighting their brittleness and the challenges faced by developers. There is skepticism about the reliability of AI systems, with concerns about the practicality of using them for coding tasks. The sentiment indicates a mix of hope for future improvements and frustration with current limitations.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the limitations of AI systems like Claude 4, noting that despite prompting for accuracy, the generated code was inefficient and flawed, reflecting the brittleness of current AI solutions in real-world applications. They suggest that while improvements may come with automated testing in software engineering, the complexity of real-world scenarios remains a significant challenge.

top_comments.author: mentalgear
top_comments.text:
Meanwhile, I asked this morning Claude 4 to write a simple EXIF normalizer. After two rounds of prompting it to double-check its code, I still had to point out that it makes no sense to load the entire image for re-orientating if the EXIF orientation is fine in the first place.
Vibe vs reality, and anyone actually working in the space daily can attest how brittle these systems are.
Maybe this changes in SWE with more automated tests in verifiable simulators, but the real world is far to complex to simulate in its vastness.

top_comments.author: coreyh14444
top_comments.text: https://theeducationist.info/everything-amazing-nobody-happy...

top_comments.author: ramon156
top_comments.text: The real question is how long it'll take until they're not brittle

top_comments.author: kubb
top_comments.text: Or will they ever be reliable. Your question is already making an assumption.

top_comments.author: diggan
top_comments.text:
> Meanwhile
What do you mean "meanwhile", that's exactly (among other things) the kind of stuff he's talking about? The various frictions and how you need to approach it

top_comments.author: fergie
top_comments.text:
There were some cool ideas- I particularly liked "psychology of AI"
Overall though I really feel like he is selling the idea that we are going to have to pay large corporations to be able to write code. Which is... terrifying.
Also, as a lazy developer who is always trying to make AI do my job for me, it still kind of sucks, and its not clear that it will make my life easier any time soon.

top_comments.author: teekert
top_comments.text:
He says that now we are in the mainframe phase. We will hit the personal computing phase hopefully soon. He says llama (and DeepSeek?) are like Linux in a way, OpenAI and Claude are like Windows and MacOS.
So, No, he’s actually saying it may be everywhere for cheap soon.
I find the talk to be refreshingly intellectually honest and unbiased. Like the opposite of a cringey LinkedIn post on AI.

top_comments.author: guappa
top_comments.text:
I think it used to be like that before the GNU people made gcc, completely destroying the market of compilers.
> Also, as a lazy developer who is always trying to make AI do my job for me, it still kind of sucks, and its not clear that it will make my life easier any time soon.
Every time I have to write a simple self contained couple of functions I try… and it gets it completely wrong.
It's easier to just write it myself rather than to iterate 50 times and hope it will work, considering iterations are also very slow.

top_comments.author: ykonstant
top_comments.text: At least proprietary compilers were software you owned and could be airgapped from any network. You didn't create software by tediously negotiating with compilers running on remote machines controlled by a tech corp that can undercut you on whatever you are trying to build (but of course they will not, it says so in the Agreement, and other tales of the fantastic).

top_comments.author: abdullin
top_comments.text:
Tight feedback loops are the key in working productively with software. I see that in codebases up to 700k lines of code (legacy 30yo 4GL ERP systems).
The best part is that AI-driven systems are fine with running even more tight loops than what a sane human would tolerate.
Eg. running full linting, testing and E2E/simulation suite after any minor change. Or generating 4 versions of PR for the same task so that the human could just pick the best one.

stories.title: Show HN: Claude Code Usage Monitor – real-time tracker to dodge usage cut-offs
stories.author: Maciej-roboblog
stories.article_summary: The Claude Code Usage Monitor is a real-time terminal tool designed for tracking Claude AI token usage, offering features such as updates every 3 seconds, visual progress bars, and smart predictions for token depletion based on current burn rates. It supports multiple plans—Pro (~7,000 tokens), Max5 (~35,000), and Max20 (~140,000)—and includes an auto-detection mode that switches to a custom limit when the Pro threshold is exceeded. Users can customize reset times and time zones, with default reset times set for every 5 hours after the first message in a session. The tool can be installed using Python 3.6+ and npm, with a simple command like `./ccusage_monitor.py --plan pro` for basic usage. As stated in the article, "Start Early: Begin monitoring when you start a new session" is a key actionable insight for effective management of token usage.

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion revolves around the installation of Python and Node tools in a self-contained manner to avoid duplication and fragility. There is an intention to implement a new feature related to machine learning and token limits using DuckDB, and a user expresses interest in documenting their findings about conversation history in a blog post.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter is seeking a method to install Python and Node tools in a self-contained manner that presents them as a single executable, avoiding duplication and fragility associated with global installations and version changes.

setup_instructions: install Python and Node tools in a self-contained way
add issue in GitHub for implementation
compatibility_issues: Node CLI tool installed globally can break with changing versions

actionable_advice: write a blog post about conversation history with metadata inside JSON lines files

top_comments.author: pbowyer
top_comments.text:
With uv, is there a way to install Python and Node tools like this in a self-contained way so they appear to the system as a single executable?
I guess I don't want to duplicate Python/Node for every tool, but I also don't want it to be fragile. And this wants a Node CLI tool installed globally, which I've found breaks easily with changing versions.

top_comments.author: Maciej-roboblog
top_comments.text: Good point, yes i can do it. If you can please add issue in github and i will implement it :D

top_comments.author: alFReD-NSH
top_comments.text: How it does it monitor usage?

top_comments.author: Maciej-roboblog
top_comments.text: Check directory ~/.claude/projects/*/*.jsonl ;) hah very interesting topic. I have a plan to write blog post about it (all conversations history with metadata inside json lines files) What do you think about this idea? Interesting?

top_comments.author: Maciej-roboblog
top_comments.text: Today, I will commit a new Auto Mode (with DuckDB) that uses machine learning to understand your actual token limits, not hardcoded solution.

stories.title: TI to invest $60B to manufacture foundational semiconductors in the U.S.
stories.author: TMWNN
stories.article_summary: Texas Instruments (TI) has announced a historic investment of over $60 billion to expand semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S., marking the largest such investment in the nation's history. This initiative includes the construction of seven semiconductor fabs across mega-sites in Texas and Utah, which will create over 60,000 jobs. TI's Sherman site alone will see up to $40 billion allocated for four fabs (SM1, SM2, SM3, and SM4), with SM1 and SM2 already in progress. CEO Haviv Ilan stated, “TI is building dependable, low-cost 300mm capacity at scale,” emphasizing the critical role these chips play in various sectors, from automotive to healthcare. Partnerships with leading companies such as Apple, Ford, Medtronic, NVIDIA, and SpaceX highlight TI's commitment to driving innovation in American manufacturing and technology.

main_themes: financialization impacting companies like Texas Instruments
shift from manufacturing to finance in large companies
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The comments reflect a critical view on corporate financialization, highlighting Texas Instruments' significant market cap and questioning their ability to invest heavily. There is a strong sentiment against war among the public, with a perception of disconnect between government actions and public opinion. Historical references to companies like General Electric and Saudi Aramco illustrate a trend of decline in once-dominant firms, emphasizing a shift from manufacturing to financial operations.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter questions Texas Instruments' ability to finance a significant investment that amounts to about a third of its market cap, suggesting that such announcements may be more about maintaining investor confidence than actual follow-through.

specific_numbers: market cap of Texas Instruments is ~170B
General Electric was once the largest non-gold asset

market_trends: financialization impacting companies like Texas Instruments
shift from manufacturing to finance in large companies
company_strategies: Texas Instruments may struggle to afford large investments
General Electric's transition to a finance arm
competitive_landscape: Saudi Aramco's decline in asset ranking
General Electric not in Top 50 anymore

top_comments.author: jppope
top_comments.text:
Someone correct me here, but Texas Instruments was one of the companies that mortgaged their future in the name of financialization (https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/yeah-its-still-water-ben-hunt...) and their market cap right now is ~170B...
How are they going to afford an investment thats ~1/3rd the value of the company? Seems like one of those announcements that no one follows up on to keep them honest?

top_comments.author: cchance
top_comments.text: They wont its another marketing scam by the admin lol, promise shit now, don't deliver reap benefits till the public/admin forgets, you dont actually have to do shit you just have to say you will same as the last time

top_comments.author: ryukoposting
top_comments.text: I find that the easiest way to suss out corporate political advertisements is to look for how they refer to the federal government. If they say "federal government" or "$NAME_OF_ACT" then there's usually at least an inkling of intent behind whatever they say next. If they say "$PRESIDENT administration" or "$PARTY_NAME," you can be certain you're reading a political advertisement.

top_comments.author: chaosbolt
top_comments.text: Yeah, meanwhile >90% of Americans don't want war, yet they will get it... "but akshually it's a republic", yeah, ruled by another country.

top_comments.author: hackernewds

General Electric was (just a few decades ago) the largest non-gold asset, and isn't even Top 50 anymore.
Saudi Aramco was (just a few years ago) the largest non-gold asset, and isn't even Top 10 anymore.
If you want to read about similarities in Xerox's own hubris/downfall, Dealers of Lightning is one of my favorite non-fiction reads of the past few years (about their SFbay PARC Labs of the 70s/80s... and its failures to adapt).

stories.title: From LLM to AI Agent: What's the Real Journey Behind AI System Development?
stories.author: codelink
stories.article_summary: The article discusses the evolution of AI systems, particularly focusing on Large Language Models (LLMs), Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), AI workflows, and AI agents. It emphasizes that while AI agents offer autonomy, simpler solutions often suffice for many applications, such as a resume-screening tool. For instance, an LLM can classify resumes as "Passed" or "Failed" using one-shot prompting, while RAG enhances this by integrating internal data for improved decision-making. Key insights include starting with simple workflows and only adopting AI agents when necessary, as well as prioritizing reliability over capability in production systems. Notably, the article suggests employing APIs for automation, such as connecting to email and calendar services to streamline recruitment processes.

stories.title: Six-month-old, solo-owned vibe coder Base44 sells to Wix for $80M cash
stories.author: myth_drannon
stories.article_summary: Israeli developer Maor Shlomo's vibe-coding startup, Base44, was acquired by Wix for $80 million just six months after its launch. Despite being a bootstrapped venture, Base44 rapidly grew to 250,000 users, generating $189,000 in profit by May, largely through word-of-mouth and Shlomo's social media presence. The platform enables users to create applications without coding by utilizing text prompts and supports various integrations, including email and analytics. Shlomo attributed the sale to the need for scaling beyond organic growth, stating, "the scale and volume we need is not something we can organically grow into," highlighting the potential of AI in startup productivity.

stories.title: Fang, the CLI Starter Kit
stories.author: bewuethr
stories.article_summary: Fang is an experimental CLI starter kit designed for Cobra applications, offering features such as fully styled help pages, error messages, and automatic versioning. It includes a hidden command for generating manpages using Mango, which enhances the appearance of documentation by utilizing roff instead of markdown. The library allows for customizable themes, supports silent usage output to improve user experience, and is easy to implement with a simple invocation of `fang.Execute` alongside a Cobra command. As part of the Charm ecosystem, Fang is open-source under the MIT license, inviting community feedback and contributions via platforms like Twitter and Discord.

agreement_points: Cross-compilation is easier in Go compared to Rust
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the challenges of cross-compilation in Rust compared to Go, emphasizing the ease of Go's static linking and the complexities introduced by Rust's dynamic linking. Tools like Goreleaser are recommended for packaging, and there is a recognition of the contributions made by Carlos, who is noted for his work on both GoReleaser and Fang.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the challenges of cross-compiling for CLI applications, noting that unlike web back-ends where the execution environment is controlled, CLI developers must cater to multiple operating systems, complicating the build process. They also mention their project, rust-starter, as a Rust equivalent to fang, utilizing Clap for command-line parsing.

hardware_specs: Apple hardware required for MacOS SDK

compatibility_issues: Rust requires system libs for dynamic linking
MacOS has technicalities with SDK usage

strong_agreements: Cross-compilation is easier in Go compared to Rust
expert_opinions: Carlos built GoReleaser and is the author of Fang

actionable_advice: Be aware of Rust's dynamic linking issues

top_comments.author: csomar
top_comments.text:
I’ve been maintaining rust-starter[!] for quite sometime now. It is kind of the equivalent of fang but for Rust. It uses Clap which is the equivalent of Cobra; though I don’t think Clap has the same kind of fancy output?
Throughout these years, I have found that cross-compiling is the most challenging part of creating a CLI. When you are building a web back-end, you control the execution environment (usually linux). For CLIs, your users could be on Linux, macOS or Windows. You need to get three x2 binaries (so a total of 6) to have a fair coverage.
I’ve tried cross, but for Windows and macOS you need licenses. There is no straightforward way to give your users Docker images and have them running in a few commands. You can compile on GitHub action machines, but that’s a very slow feedback loop. I wonder if things are better in Go land.
!: https://github.com/rust-starter/rust-starter

top_comments.author: neomantra
top_comments.text:
Golang itself bundles a toolchain and can cross compile to a many target OSes and architectures. I use Goreleaser [1] to create GitHub releases, Homebrew packages, Docker images, and Linux packages. Goreleaser Pro can also create MSI packages.
ETA since I just saw Christian chime in: the Goreleaser author works at Charm.sh =)
[1] https://goreleaser.com

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
GoReleaser is indeed an awesome tool and we use it for every applicable project.
And actually Carlos, who builds GoReleaser, is the true author of Fang and took it from concept to execution.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: Wow TIL cross compilation is a bit of a pain in Rust. I assumed it was as easy as Go. I can confirm as long as you're using pure Go (no cgo), it's as easy as setting $GOOS and $GOARCH appropriately.

top_comments.author: paulddraper
top_comments.text:
The difficulty is due to Rust dynamically linking and Go statically linking. The former requires the system libs.
That said, I am unfamiliar with any licensing for Windows builds.
MacOS has some niche (usually discarded) technicalities like you can only use the SDK on Apple hardware.

top_comments.author: threemux
top_comments.text: I think that's a reference to the use of Docker in the "cross" tool that makes cross compilation easier but I'm not certain

top_comments.author: christianrocha
top_comments.text:
I feel your pain. That said, cross compiling from Go is pretty trivial, as long as everything is pure Go, which it most often is. That’s one if the reasons we invested in jt.
(Hello from Charm! I’m one of the authors of this library.)

top_comments.author: mootoday
top_comments.text:
This is great, lots I learned by looking at your code and the dependencies you use!
I started a similar thing, although not as feature-rich as yours. My goal was to follow CLI best practices and add all the boilerplate one needs to build a Rust CLI.
https://github.com/mootoday/cli-template

top_comments.author: rmac
top_comments.text:
I looked into how rust does does it for rustup, and they have a pretty amazing set of gh actions to build for their architectures, I can't find the GH link now tho
for speed you can look for vendors like https://depot.dev/

top_comments.author: johnisgood
top_comments.text:
I just ran across "gum"[1] from charmbracelet which I intend to use! I just want to replace dialog. I came across whiptail, too, but gum seems nicer.
They have a TUI framework, too, among a lot of other related things. Some of their projects are Go libraries, some are a CLI tool, such as gum.
[1] https://github.com/charmbracelet/gum

stories.title: Writing documentation for AI: best practices
stories.author: mooreds
stories.article_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of high-quality documentation for AI systems, particularly Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) frameworks like Kapa, which relies on well-structured content to generate accurate responses. Key components include a retriever that searches documentation, a vector database for storage, and a generator (LLM) that formulates answers. It underscores that "poor documentation doesn't just frustrate human readers; it directly degrades the quality of AI responses," highlighting the necessity for explicit and self-contained content chunks to improve AI accuracy. Actionable insights include using standardized semantic HTML, avoiding PDFs in favor of HTML or Markdown, and ensuring semantic clarity in URLs, which collectively enhance machine readability and retrieval efficiency.

main_themes: Limited discussion with detailed analysis available
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a shared understanding that good documentation and SEO practices align with effective software engineering principles. Participants emphasize the importance of clear structure and meaningful content, while also noting the tendency for some practices to prioritize algorithmic compliance over genuine utility.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the irony that enhancing documentation for AI compatibility aligns closely with the principles of effective documentation, such as clear context, structured organization, and precise error messaging.

top_comments.author: emil_sorensen
top_comments.text: OP here. It's kind of ironic that making the docs AI-friendly essentially just ends up being what good documentation is in the first place (explicit context and hierarchy, self-contained sections, precise error messages).

top_comments.author: shafyy
top_comments.text: It's the same for SEO also. Good structure, correct use of HTML elements, quick loading, good accessibility, etc. Sure, there are "tricks" to improve your SEO, but the general principles are also good if you were not doing SEO.

top_comments.author: klysm
top_comments.text: And yet in practice SEO slop garbage is SEO slop garbage. Devoid of any real meaning or purpose other than to increase rankings and metrics. Nobody cares if it’s good or useful, but it must appease the algorithm!

top_comments.author: jilles
top_comments.text: It's similar for writing code. Suddenly people are articulating their problems to the LLM and breaking it down in smaller sub-problems to solve....

top_comments.author: arscan
top_comments.text: In other words, people are discovering the value of standard software engineering practices. Which, I think is a good thing.

top_comments.author: corysama
top_comments.text: It has changed how I structure my code. Out of laziness, if I can write the code in such a way that each step follows naturally from what came before, "the code just writes itself!" Except now it's literally true :D

top_comments.author: appreciatorBus
top_comments.text: Maybe everyone already discovered this but I find that if I include a lot of detail in my variables names, it's much more likely to autocomplete something useful. If whatever I typed was too verbose for my liking long term, I can always clean it up later with a rename.

top_comments.author: bobbiechen
top_comments.text:
Related: "If an AI agent can't figure out how your API works, neither can your users" (from my employer's blog)
https://stytch.com/blog/if-an-ai-agent-cant-figure-out-how-y...

top_comments.author: Cthulhu_
top_comments.text:
It's a good tool to use for code reviewing, especially if you don't have peers with Strong Opinions on it.
Which is another issue, indifference. It's hard to find people that actually care about things like API design, let alone multiple that check each other's work. In my experience, a lot of the time people just get lazy and short-circuit the reviews to "oh he knows what he's doing, I'm sure he thought long and hard about this".

top_comments.author: thom
top_comments.text: Yeah, I've started to think AI smoke tests for cognitive complexity should be a fundamental part of API/schema design now. Even if you think the LLMs are dumb, Stupidity as a Service is genuinely useful.

actionable_insights_summary.summary:
**Executive Summary:**

Texas Instruments' $60B investment in U.S. semiconductor manufacturing signals a robust opportunity for software solutions tailored to this sector; consider forming partnerships with TI and investing in semiconductor startups. Additionally, the rising demand for AI documentation tools highlights a market gap for standardized solutions, prompting the need to develop such tools and educate clients on their importance. Lastly, the increasing interest in CLI tools for Go applications presents an opportunity to create a premium toolkit, necessitating engagement with the Fang community and potential partnerships within the Go ecosystem.
